entities.text: ⚠️Correlation ≠ causation. The controls in this study only account for topic and publication venue. These "influencers" don't tweet random papers, and any skill they have in picking promising papers can explain why this study finds that they eventually accrue more citations.

Related, possibly controversial:

As a rule of thumb, if the abstract uses the phrase "We present/propose", I regard it with greater skepticism. It sounds to me like the authors are marketing a product, and you should always be skeptical of marketing.

(skeptical ≠ disbelieving)
Sorry to disappoint you. Inspired by this paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782
, I did the same thing by clicking the promote button on the top right corner of the post and spending x hundred bucks trying to promote it:
x.com/simon_zhai/sta…

. 

But honestly, it is very hard to use this "promote", and an "ads specialist" from Twitter actually called me sometimes trying to teach me how to do advertisements better. 😀

In case anyone wants to advertise their work better, do not naively click the prompt button like I did, as it will throw your posts to some random people. I was taught to use this
ads.x.com

to make the promotion more "targeted", but it will cost more as well. 

[quote from an anonymous friend from CVPR] These days doing research is just crazily hard as one needs to do:
1. front end eng (preparing for project website)
2. back end eng (code up the project)
3. demo (teaser fig / gif / video)
4. advertisement (on social media)

It's all fun and games until people start paying "AI influencers" to advertise their papers.

Perhaps journal publication fees became a thing partly in this way (?) But as opposed to publication fees, there is no peer reviewing on these social media accounts. So it's even worse.
This is not a fortunate situation and science should not work like this.
Influencers are permeating science communication as curators of work that gets further academic/societal clout. We discussed further implications of AI academic influencers in our

paper (w

probably true for VC in AI as well. Many recent AI startups whose valuations are entirely based on founder poasting ability
Being tweeted about by

entities.name: Aran Komatsuzaki
entities.text: @arankomatsuzaki
is more selective than any ML venue (and probably

entities.name: AK
entities.text: @_akhaliq

too)

Check out "Tweets to Citations: Unveiling the Impact of Social Media Influencers on AI Research Visibility" to see the impact on your citations.
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782
[SI] Tweets to Citations: Unveiling the Impact of Social Media Influencers on AI Research Visibility
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782

Social media influencers significantly increase the citation counts of machine learning research papers they share, with median citation counts 2-3 times higher than control group. The study reveals the expanding influence of social media in scholarly communication and highlights the importance of a balanced and diverse research ecosystem. The findings emphasize the need for responsible curation practices by influencers and conference organizers to ensure a comprehensive understanding of research quality and relevance.
[30/30] 67 Likes, 47 Comments, 1 Posts
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782

cs․DL | cs․AI | cs․CL | cs․CV | cs․LG | cs․SI, 24 Jan 2024

🆕Tweets to Citations: Unveiling the Impact of Social Media Influencers on AI Research Visibility

Iain Xie Weissburg, Mehir Arora, Liangmi...

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: As the number of accepted papers at AI and ML conferences reaches into the thousands, it has become unclear how researchers access and read research publications.  In this paper, we investigate the role of social media influencers in enhancing the visibility of machine learning research, particularly the citation counts of papers they share.  We have compiled a comprehensive dataset of over 8,000 papers, spanning tweets from December 2018 to October 2023, alongside 1:1 matched controls based on publication year, venue, and abstract topics.  Our analysis reveals a significant increase in citations for papers endorsed by these influencers, with median citation counts 2-3 times higher than those of the control group.  Additionally, the study delves into the geographic, gender, and institutional diversity of highlighted authors.  These findings highlight the expanding influence of social media in scholarly communication and underscore the importance of an evolving ecosystem in today's d...

entities.text: 📈🤓 Ever wondered how a social media shoutout can impact AI research visibility? 🌐 Our new research shows significant connections between influencers and AI paper citations. A must-read for anyone in the
#MachineLearning

community! 

📜Preprint:
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782
(They also compare the review scores)
True but it's been shown before that review scores are uncorrelated with future impact/citations anyway.

No, we did try to control for quality by looking at open review scores. We did not claim any causal conclusions: all we are saying is that the endorsed papers are have significantly higher citations than controls.

👎You totally suggest a causal effect, reading your title alone. And everyone I heard took it as a conclusion of your paper. But of course a conservative title wouldn't have been as popular. And review scores were shown before to be uncorrelated with citations🤷
Exactly. And the community doesn’t decide to follow people at random. We follow people that reliably post papers we find interesting

entities.name: AK
entities.text: @_akhaliq
has an opportunity here to prospectively inject a small amount of randomness into their paper choices for a while, measure some effects, and settle this once and for all.
Elon literally pays us, I make $20-100/month from twitter

You are sharing papers you find to be interesting. It turns out your taste matches with others and they follow you. This helps Elon make money and he shares some of it with you. I think this is perfectly fine as long as he doesn't tell you what paper to advertise or not advertise
And the academia is discussing this on twitter now 😅

Discussions are fine, we don't (and shouldn't) review each other's opinion before saying it anyway. But it would be bad if there were discussion influencers, too. Like politics where it is a whole industry to pump up ideas. I don't want academia to go that route.
Until? It's already happening.
I am not aware of such a scheme but I am not that active on Twitter as you may tell, so I am probably missing something. If it's happening, it's bad.

Caveats about this not being an interventional study aside, this study assumes that papers published at the same conf on similar topics should be similarly cited on avg.

But, the conf cycle is out of sync with ML speed, and I wonder how much of this is just first-to-market bias.

Yes, there is correlation vs causation issue, too. But I think it is true that papers shared by those influencers will get more citations as they are more visible. I am okay with this. My concern is, there is no mechanism against those influencers doing paid promotions.

Is this meaningfully different from the previous status quo, in which established non-social-media "influencers" (ie, well-known researchers giving talks) impacted which papers got traction and which didn't?

I think the difference is quite huge. How many people do you reach through talks (where you present your own papers, so ... not so many) and how many people do you reach with almost 300k followers, tweeting regularly?
How about hypothesis, that they recommend interesting for many people and good papers in general?
I prefer the hypothesis that this should not be centralized to 2 people.
Good study. The paper doesn’t address the additional issue of influence during the review period. I suspect the same issues apply.
I think it is causation vs correlation. They already select high quality papers, it is not that the papers they select suddenly start getting more citations.

there you go. Related to your question about why I support double-blind over SP wild-west

🧠✈️ People don't do "fundamental science" in 🇨🇴 & LATAM as our ecosystem isn't as rich & bold as the one of 🇺🇸🇬🇧🇫🇷🇩🇪 etc.
I can spot old Empires. Alienation by legacy? 🤔

someone just confirmed to me that a student spent several hundred dollars to advertise their paper on twitter/X after I posted a screenshot in my lab chat of getting said ad on my timeline. This is very disappointing
What's wrong with that? They should be applauded for it!
I’m not sure whether students should or shouldn’t spend hundreds on advertising. But the main disappointment is ai research has reached this stage where people feel compelled to do this
Why is it disappointing? Isn't it their paper and their money?

it’s disappointing because it’s a reflection of the very crappy state of academia and research in AI. People feel compelled to have to do this. As others have said this perhaps now is a smart move but ideally this shouldn’t ever be necessary

Absolutely nothing wrong in promoting your own original work. If their work really was sub-par, the scientific community can identify it. In fact, publicizing one’s work is a double edged sword. It opens your work to extra scrutiny, and so you should acknowledge the downside too

i can agree here. I find the disappointing part partially to be that people feel the need to do this as well as the misaligned incentives. The ultimate outcome is still judged on the work itself for most research

A lesson I learned the hard way is that academic research *is* content marketing. Your job is literally to create marketing materials (papers, talks, etc) for your personal + advisor's brand.

It's always been about popularity-maxing.
I understand this point pretty well (hence having a twitter account) but personally feel spending money on ads is a step too far for me but may become the norm in the future amongst students

I get your frustration, but large industrial labs have marketing expenses in the 100Ks to do similar. Well-funded academics travel to more events/labs to evangelize their work. If it's any consolation, I think running Twitter ads is not an effective way to advertise.

I’m actually less frustrated that a student  is trying to get ahead (it makes sense given companies spend a ton) but more frustrated at the state of research in AI. To feel the need to try and spend money is not a good sign but it very much may become the norm

I got curious about my most successful paper not tweeted about by Aran and my least successful paper tweeted about by him. It looks like the former is RWKV w/ 101 cites since May 22, 2023 published in Findings of EMNLP 2023. Was surprised he didn't X it
arxiv.org/abs/2305.13048

And the later is BLOOM+1 w/ 18 cites since Dec 18, 2022 published in ACL 2023. I thought this was a really good paper and it's always confused me why it's gotten so few cites. It was my first paper as a senior advisor, which was an interesting experience
arxiv.org/abs/2212.09535
ahem i was left out

x.com/scobleizer/lis…

isn’t the bar for being “more selective than any ML venue” just “tweet less than 3 papers a day”?
I didn't understand what exactly in this paper showed the effect is causation (as claimed by authors), and not just correlation. Afaikt that claim is not supported by data.
Well, selective true, but under very different constraints.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: AIやMLの学会で採択された論文の数が数千に達するにつれ、研究者がどのように研究論文にアクセスし、読むのかが不明確になってきた。本稿では、機械学習研究の認知度向上におけるソーシャルメディアインフルエンサーの役割、特に彼らが共有する論文の引用数を調査する。2018年12月から2023年10月までのツイートにまたがる8,000を超える論文の包括的なデータセットを、出版年、開催地、抄録トピックに基づく1対1のマッチング対照とともに作成した。分析によると、これらのインフルエンサーが支持した論文の被引用回数は大幅に増加し、中央値は対照群の2～3倍であった。さらに、この研究では、ハイライトされた著者の地理的、性別、所属機関の多様性についても掘り下げている。これらの調査結果は、学術コミュニケーションにおけるソーシャルメディアの影響力の拡大を浮き彫りにし、今日のデジタルな学術状況における進化するエコシステムの重要性を強調している。

entities.text: As the number of accepted papers at AI and ML conferences reaches into the thousands, it has become unclear how researchers access and read research publications. We investigate the role of influencers in enhancing machine learning research visibility. 🧵2/6

A common intuition for this correlation is that influencers tweet papers with higher quality or hot topics. Our comprehensive dataset of tweeted papers, alongside 1:1 matched controls based on publication venue and precise topic, which we show controls for paper quality 🧵 3/6

We've discovered a significant trend: papers shared by social media influencers receive 2-3 times more citations than their non-tweeted counterparts. This finding highlights the influence of social media in elevating academic work and reshaping scholarly communication.🧵 4/6

Delving deeper, our analysis also sheds light on diversity. We find that the geographic and gender diversity of authors in influencer-endorsed papers reflects that of the wider community, and we make recommendations to foster responsible growth in the
#AIResearch
community 🧵 5/6
📜Preprint:
arxiv.org/abs/2401.13782

Many thanks to the Co-authors:
Mehir Arora

speak for yourself I’m still just following people at random lol 

my kingdom for a curated list
I used a script to follow people that I’ve “like”d multiple times. So you can treat my following list as a curated list :)
Ftm bias is a really good point that I haven’t seen others making!
yeah agreed, but this still seems like a difference in degree rather than a difference in kind.
Monetization is the difference. AK is no longer an independent poster. He’s made a career of it.

I might actually argue this alternative is better, since
1) these influencers act independently
2) their motivation to maintain / gain followers leads to selecting both good & diverse papers

Also, analysis uses publication venue and year as a proxy for quality, not too fair.

I don't know, to make a comparison: 'rule by one' is not the same kind as 'rule by  many' just because you "only" divided the number of decision makers from N to 1. It's a completely different thing in nature.
Oh, I fully support that. Let's add at least me there?)
They do recommend good papers, but the fields they focus on are limited. I believe this is helping lead to further homogeneity in research.
I would say that they try to focus on "general paper" and "not theory".
Yeah they also select papers in specific categories which tend to be much more busy/visible (LLMs, generative models, etc.)
Agreed, I'd want to see a controlled experiment, which seems impossible.

But hasn't science worked like this so far? Scientist are aware of papers because someone recommended them (at a conference/talk/seminar/review/social circle) etc. This is just showing that lots of scientists are "friends" with influencers and get recommended papers.

Science still works this way, but here we have a centralized influence by 2 people, whose decisions at a given day have an impact on the whole community. Not one person making a recommendation to a friend.

There are simply too many papers vying for the same eyeballs. Social media is at least biased in the direction of what attracts genuine interest; rather than gatekeeping journal editors or the privileged few able to attend conferences.

why do you think it's bad? If he spent his own money, your paper is sort of "product" and thus, can be advertised and cited more.

research is a competition too, after all

Yes it’s a competition and yes research these days has become more influenced by popularity and marketing in AI. I don’t think this creates the right incentives for research. In theory you can do low quality work and signal boost it with money instead of doing good work
Promoted as an actual twitter advertisement or did they pay somebody to retweet it, like an influencer?
twitter advertisement, paid for by the student
There is nothing wrong with promoting your work. This is not disappointing.
if the way you get a leg up in visibility is via paid ads instead of high quality work, it can create the wrong incentives in research imo
It’s the research twitter endgame if this becomes a thing
This is going to be new norm
what exactly is the disappointment here? they ran an ad about their paper with their money?
what's the paper?

Ask them to sneak in some random papers daily as well :D 

On a serious note, I think comparing their early years when they didn't have the follower count vs the more recent ones could be a way

Oh yeah that's a great idea! I guess one could also measure whether the post engagements, retweets & likes, as a proxy for # of impressions correlate with # of citations a certain amount of time later?

It seems to be the affiliation and therefore the location of the authors, so I'm even more surprised by the result. I have the feeling that Asia (in particular Singapore, Japan, China and South Korea) is over-represented in top papers
I think it's not reach only but also the degree of centralisation. Personally, I could name many more "well known researchers" than influencer accounts.

Are we seriously focusing on the monetization of the influencer instead of the scientists?

Brain drainage is a thing. As a researcher who left 🇨🇴 for more appealing lands, I dislike running science as a vanity contest. It inherently promotes ✈️🧠, no?

Pls 📊 on science funds!
This emoji language I don’t understand
But it’s a free market. Somebody wanna change something go challenge, if you idea has real value and majority agrees, you will be able to change. Otherwise let’s just appreciate him for his work.
Yes, but it’s “general papers” largely in areas like LLMs, diffusion, NeRF/splats, or other trendy areas.

I think influence of well-known scientists was/is still centralized. A few can be king-makers by praising a work and recommending it to their large number of students/colleagues or mentioning it in a talk. Also, there are more influencers than just the two studied in the paper.
I imagine the influence of these two is easier to study but overall I’d expect even bigger impact of the Google scholar and Twitter recommendation algorithms on science.
whats the status of rwkv now? heard they jusy landed funding.

I should've tweeted about RWKV paper, but I think I was being a bit busy / lazy on the day of the release. I tend to tweet only the papers that are released on the day of the tweet. If a tweet was made by someone else (other than AK), then I don't tweet but just retweet to give better visibility to the author. I also spend less time for tweeting than people think. Overall, there are so many papers I miss.

There are many great papers that have been cited very few, which is a pity. A good recent example is that Group Query Attention paper got only 36 citations
arxiv.org/abs/2305.13245

Ahmad, we collected a dataset of shared papers and select randomized control samples based on pub details, topics, & paper quality using review scores. The comparisons with various versions of controls show that the shared papers have statistically significantly higher citations.

Thanks for the clarification. Review scores are quite random and not indicative of quality. 

There is likely other confounds that could lead to selection of these papers which are correlated with excitement at a glance. 

I'm still unsure how you concluded a casual relationship.
That's a good point. I'd like to know the answer to that.
can anyone please walk me through the maths how the investment in ads money spent can come back to them in returns
It's not disappointing. It's their work.
Oh ffs.. Guess that's totally predictable in retrospect
I'm guessing the disappointment comes from such a clear reminder that science exists within in a capitalist grind. This is actually a good thing to highlight and talk about, I think.
The real question is whether paying for twitter adspace was more effective than getting akhaliq to post about the paper.
If they want make a commercial product, that's ok.

In some ways, this is life.

People spend money for a possible ROI, which can be measured in different ways.

Research is not that different...

A caveat is that some research and related activities is still publicly funded, wherein accountability may matter.
I respect the act of advertising, but the trend is a bit disheartening.

The student clearly thought the paper was excellent, enough to put money up for it.

Was the student right?

It appears to me that those accounts are almost comparable to venues: I'm happy to report that my paper has been accepted to AKs feed. The impact factor seems to be significant. Acceptance is decided by a one person committee that presumably does not read the papers in detail.

🤣 as my advisor once said the same
🇨🇴 := Colombia
✈️🧠 := Brain drainage
Pls 📊 on science funds := Let's focus on the impact of social media on the distribution of science funds
What impact are we talking about though? I can see an argument of intimidating reviewers when authors of papers under review are de-anonymised through tweets influencers.

Ah I don’t mean reviews, I mean shaping research interests. As a made up example, the community may bias towards video over image understanding because the former comes with videos, so the posts get boosted by X and people perceive it as more trendy than it really is.

It’s impossible to list all confounds but we do control for topics & pub details. There’s no perfect measure of paper quality. Also, we do not claim X causes Y. We show the exp set has a significant increase in citations for papers endorsed by these influencers, than the control.

To be clear, I'm not saying the situation is ideal/fair, but elements of influence were part of "the game" before. Now, the rules have changed somewhat, but the general idea of disseminating research/papers/ideas is still part of being (a popular?) scientist.

Yes, the endorsement is correlated with citations. Maybe that's why they have become influencers to begin with? 

Several others are posting papers and haven't got traction.
Maybe consider paying for some promotion as well? It’s just an investment
Nature journals let you pay to make your paper open access, which has similar energy
Nothing wrong with this. Most rsearch papers are paper weights. If you think your research is worth something, better to spend some shekels to spread the word.

But the paper is talking about citations. So, making your paper more popular/citable is part of the job. It is similar to making an effort of writing the paper well, creating nice figures, preparing a video and website, etc. What is different now? The centralisation of influence?

Ok. Similarly a paper being mentioned on TV/magazine or in a university/company press release. Is that also boosting how people perceive a research and shape the research interests of the community? What is wrong with that?
Nothing inherently, it’s just the influence of Twitter more in the shadows then outright sponsoring of conferences and scholarships

Yeah agreed. I wish more high-profile researchers would tweet more! It seems like this category of AI-social-media influencers has arisen due to senior researchers somewhat abdicating their role in the ecosystem when it comes to social media.
I bet many of them feel affirmed in their abstinence seeing where X is headed.

Good question. But we were not trying to answer this question in this paper. My personal guess is that I find the quality of their endorsed papers is much higher than reading random arxiv announcements, therefore for me, the information gain is higher in search of good paper.

The title is "tweets to citations". How is that not a casual claim?  And after the colon it is repeated,  "unveiling the impact of social media influencers on ai research visibility".  If you are telling a story of correlations, don't put causality in the title twice.
Yes, it can very well be that they have a great taste in selecting papers :-)
I know what you mean, but isn't paying thousands of dollars to fly across the world to present at CVPR  (or any other conference) also advertising?

i feel like a lot of people misunderstand my post a bit. I mean it’s fine to advertise (i do it frequently myself, twitter, conferences etc) but getting to the stage of paid twitter advertisements is kind of crazy to me. Maybe it’s just the new age of academia
I raised this exact point during

entities.name: Defence Research Network
entities.text: @DefenceResNet

's Twitter hour last month. The biggest disconnect between academia and research in any field and the public is communication. Many people refuse to use the scientific method or believe in science because academia and research are so alien to everyday people.

Every well-known professor spends a considerable amount of time in the limelight and gets free press that results in research grants, the ability to hire more research students, students, etc. 

What's the issue when students do the same? Let's encourage everyone to rebuild their trust in science by communicating and teaching students how to build their social media presence. Communication has been a critical challenge for students who spend too much time researching related activities.

And I agree with you on that one. Although your work will only be judged by it’s academic merit, and there’s downside to publicizing your work, you still gain unfair advantage over someone whose work was more impactful but did not promote. I guess it’s

entities.name: #CVPR2024
entities.text: @CVPR
job to pick a side.
That’s right - what a naive take by the OP.
research is obsolete its all become a money game
everything is about money in some extent, especially where researchers are really getting paid for their jobs :)

I see your point. Nonetheless, I believe that scientific community could distinguish good from bad, this may incentivise community notes and encourage researchers to promote their work. Maybe, we should accept new rules of the game, or maybe not. Tough.

Thank you for the reply.
Demonic vision of research

I'd put 'mercantile' instead of 'demonic'. It really doesn't contradict the origins of philosophy of science. Francis Bacon meant science as driver of the industry. Might be a good thing to use industry to drive the science, don't know.
community notes on research would be awesome. Just don’t know if there will ever be enough traction to get those things up though

Now apply the same logic to what you consider good work. Surely greater and broader reach is a good thing?

Another way to frame this is what kind of game is research? If it's a zero-sum game, then spending $ for reach is negative for other researchers. If it's a positive sum game, which I believe it is, then efficient audience building is a net positive.

Wild, first time I'm hearing of that. 

In a way it's not so different from paying to attend yet another workshop/symposium to promote your work, but it shouldn't become the norm

Alright, here's a walk-through. Read carefully: it's complicated and unexpected. 
 - Student gets a job when they graduate because someone learned about their work from the ad. 
 - Job pays a salary of in excess of a few hundred dollars. 

See where this is going?
Because they were probably trying to influence the best paper award
I guess it depends: visibility is crucial for others to adopt your work.
Dude why you advertising CVPR in your username and showing your university in your bio. Get a leg up and publish in Hardware lol and mention your high school instead on your papers

Ivy League universities commonly pay PR agents to place stories about research of their profs in the news. 🤷‍♂️ Who knows how many brilliant ideas are burried out there in conference archives unknown to the public because authors did not bother to promote them enough. Ads are smart

didn’t even know this was a thing…

i don’t think ads really help long run for research papers but it’s insane someone considered it as a viable option, a poor reflection of the state of academic research
Ok but let’s not pretend like current incentives in research are all right

well I think its about why they do this.

but tbh if you target the ads very specific you can get the right people to read your paper, which could lead to a job etc.

or just show off your awsome work.

It doesn't matter.

E.g. you wrote a nice article, you're proud of it. Social media is basically created to share such work. Paying for an ad to get your work in front of more eyes is paying to make science more accessible.
I think the centralization, yes. And in my case I care less about AK whom people choose to follow and more about Google/Twitter who choose what I see based on unclear cues.

This is "just" winner-take-all mechanism of popularity. You see what others liked seeing on X/Google. Similarly, you cite what others have cited when reading papers. The winner-take-all of paper popularity in science was always present as science is a social game.
There is a huge literature on causal inference, it isn't just "match on observables" or "RCT"!
Anyway; great data and analysis!! It's good to see the significant correlation between these endorsements and citations (that is intuitively expected) be explicitly shown in a data driven manner.

The study doesn't show that their endorsement causes citations; it's merely correlated. 

Perhaps you should write good papers that win both their endorsement and the citations :-)
Why is it bad? Math research is also social and you could say Gowers and Tao are major influencers by virtue of being active online

Unlike math, deep money in deep learning means recommendations from influencers are not always for the merit. Plus AI folks have big lab bias. The AKs are well-informed and yet predictably miss gems from small groups while tweeting out ok-ish results from big labs, adding to whatever exponent factor big labs enjoy in citation network effects. 

Finally, if you consider influencers outside of the AKs (the majority of the influencers), most don't even have a strong AI research experience but have built a large following using social media growth tactics. And many of them are incentive-driven.  So comparisons to Tao or Gowers don't hold for AI.

Also, being most online != being an influencer (it's a necessary but not sufficient condition)

Hard to imagine how they could control for that.  Other than basing it on citation counts, how can one objectively determine the relevance, perceived quality and impact of the selected papers vs 'average' paper?
You can design a study where the participants tweet 50% randomly assigned papers and 50% of the papers they would usually tweet.
Sure, a RCT would be preferable, but the authors argue that they successfully controlled for quality at least (not sure about relevance and impact though)

That’s true because there are a lot of confounding variables and we cannot directly conduct interventions on AKs. But from various of randomly sampled controls data conditioned on venue, topic, paper quality, the exp set has statistically significantly more citations than control

Ok, true, but people like these two academic research "influencers" would never damage their reputation that way, right?  I haven't read the paper either, but it sounds like more of an "observational study" vs RCT.

Yeah maybe they won’t, but tweeting a randomly selected paper doesn’t sound like a super bad thing to do. Sometimes it just takes a bit of effort to get a study right. Until then, we still won’t know whether tweeting influences citations counts.
Right, that’s exactly why we consider matching topics in the control set, so that this would not happen.
That’s not the case. We control for paper quality as well, using conference review scores in open review.
Now, if the authors had only counted overall citations to papers about causality, I'd be totally convinced of their claim.
I have been meaning to make a site that tracks when papers release code/weight, my pet peeve, so perhaps that can help a tad 😁

If it was reputation damaging, then that means their selection process is informed. 

It’s hard for me to assume the selection process of these Twitter accounts is not informed. There’s a ton of uninteresting articles. They tweet the interesting ones or they don’t get followers.

It's laughable to think that controlling for review scores could allow you to infer causation. First, you do not control for them. You just plot the means between "control" and "treatment." Second, even if you did, that would be only a weak proxy for the citeability of papers.
What's wrong with

entities.name: Papers with Code
entities.text: @paperswithcode

Analysis: <1750783274916393329> questioned the causal claim made in the paper's title, arguing that the data only supports correlation. <1750813649143222704> clarified the methodology and acknowledged the lack of a causal link.

<1750857474108739706> suggested that influencers tend to select high-impact papers, thus the correlation. <1750868046581768238> proposed a randomized controlled trial where influencers tweet randomly assigned papers to determine the true impact.

<1751077094220579134> criticized the paper's title for suggesting causality when the analysis only shows correlation. <1751190579906547820> agreed and suggested revising the title to reflect the correlational nature of the findings.
Other discussions touched upon the influence of paper topic, author fame, and other PR activities on citation counts, highlighting the difficulty in isolating the impact of influencer tweets.
Conclusion: <1750938326096372052> questions whether influencers *cause* increased citations or simply select papers already predisposed to high citation counts due to their inherent qualities.

Abstract: <1751279042375057724> raised concerns about paid promotion of research papers by "AI influencers" on social media, likening it to journal publication fees but lacking peer review. <1751418052447739923> mentioned receiving payments for sharing papers, while <1751503718586220571> clarified that sharing interesting papers and gaining followers is acceptable if there's no external influence on the content shared.
Introduction: <1750758512307929443> argues that research is a social activity and discovering papers by traditional means is no longer feasible. <1750759080652616117> expresses concern about this trend. <1750761396684701742> counters by citing mathematicians like Gowers and Tao as examples of positive online influence.

<1750767115085263228> points out that financial incentives and "big lab bias" in AI/ML make comparisons to math inaccurate. They argue that many AI/ML influencers lack strong research experience and rely on social media tactics.

<1750820274503626941> discusses the difficulty of discovering papers organically and suggests a platform similar to "Product Hunt" for papers. <1750820428468117752> mentions creating a site that tracks code/weight releases.
<1750766514586993135> criticizes the paper's methodology for not adequately controlling for the quality of papers shared by influencers.
Analysis: <1750949584258404632> suggested a correlation between project page existence and citation count, hypothesizing that influencers favor well-visualized work, potentially increasing reach and citations.
<1750878238681768110> questioned whether influencers are genuinely skilled at selecting impactful papers or if their success is primarily due to chance.
Discussion: <1750836982341652567> pointed out the paper doesn't address influence during the review process. <1750838361785242041> argued that science has always involved recommendations, while <1750840323725570264> highlighted the centralized nature of influence by a few individuals.
<1750770701093785724> predicted that academic papers will become more like marketing tools, similar to what's observed in large AI research organizations.

<1803466627679146428> saw no issue with promoting research, but <1803487356827414749> argued that prioritizing visibility over quality creates wrong incentives. <1803563678484025738> pointed out that universities already pay for PR, suggesting ads are just another form of promotion.
Conclusion: <1750732070014337101> highlighted the impact of AI/ML influencers on citation counts, suggesting a 'TikTokification' of academia. <1750906524497842423> questioned the study's lack of randomization, viewing it as a publicity stunt.

<1803351110037430596> argued that researchers paying for promotion is acceptable as research is a competition. <1803487713120887176> countered that this incentivizes low-quality work over good research.
Other discussions explored the potential of community notes in research evaluation and the role of open-source code in long-term impact.

Data Collection: <1751579392965321018> inquired about the availability of the dataset used in the analysis.
<1750850092125294990> questioned whether videos from a specific content creator (@ykilcher) were included in the analysis.
Analysis: <1750785464154358148> asked for a summary of how the authors established causality rather than just correlation between influencer tweets and citation counts.
Conclusion: <1750936587683438899> questioned if social media influencers are merely replacing the role previously held by established researchers who gave talks and influenced paper traction. <1750938777218863546> argued that the scale of reach is significantly different.
<1750941773961089526> compared influencer accounts to venues with substantial impact factors, where acceptance is decided by a single person who may not thoroughly review the papers.

<1751028461857038464> suggested that influencers might improve the system by promoting a wider range of papers due to their incentive to gain followers. They also criticized the paper's reliance on publication venue and year as a proxy for quality.
Other discussions revolved around the monetization of influencers and its potential effects on scientific discourse, as well as the broader implications for funding and "brain drain".

Related Work: <1752425165793759366> mentioned a related EMNLP 2023 paper [[aclanthology.org/2023.emnlp-mai…]] that discusses the broader implications of AI academic influencers in science communication, complementing the provided paper's focus on citation impact by exploring the wider societal effects.

Critique.Analysis: The authors compared citation counts of papers shared by AI/ML influencers on Twitter with a control group of similar papers.  They found a statistically significant difference, with shared papers having higher citations. However, they acknowledged the study only demonstrates correlation, not causation.
Critique.Conclusion: The authors studied the impact of AI/ML influencers on academic paper visibility and citations, finding that influencer-endorsed papers receive significantly more citations. They suggest this necessitates a re-evaluation of traditional academic processes.

Perspective.Abstract: The authors investigated the impact of social media influencers on the visibility and citation counts of machine learning research papers. Their analysis revealed that papers shared by influencers received significantly more citations compared to a control group.
Perspective.Introduction: The authors explore the role of AI/ML influencers on Twitter (X) in disseminating research, focusing on two specific individuals. They analyze the impact of these influencers' endorsements on paper citation counts, acknowledging potential biases while advocating for responsible curation.
Perspective.Analysis: The authors investigated the correlation between social media promotion by AI/ML influencers and the citation counts of research papers. They found a statistically significant positive correlation, suggesting that influencer sharing is a strong indicator of future research impact.
Perspective.Discussion: The authors analyze how influential researchers on social media affect paper visibility in machine learning. They discuss the implications of this trend, particularly regarding equity and diversity in research dissemination, and propose recommendations for improvement.
Perspective.Conclusion: The authors studied the impact of AI/ML influencers on paper citations. They found that papers promoted by influencers receive significantly more citations, raising questions about the changing dynamics of academic recognition and the role of social media in research dissemination.

Q&A.Data Collection: The authors investigated the impact of AI/ML influencers on paper citations by comparing papers tweeted by influencers to a control group. They matched papers based on publication year, venue, topic, and author prominence.  The control group was selected from papers published in the same venues and years.
Q&A.Analysis: The authors investigated whether tweets by AI/ML influencers correlate with higher citation counts for research papers. Comparing papers tweeted by influencers against a control group, they found a statistically significant difference in citation counts.  However, correlation doesn't imply causation, so they further investigated a causal link.
Q&A.Conclusion: The authors studied the impact of AI/ML influencers on social media, particularly focusing on how endorsements from figures like AK affect paper citations.  They found that influencer-endorsed papers receive significantly more citations, highlighting their role in shaping research visibility.
